column40: has become one of the most popular gull species in southwest China in recent years. There has been no information on the gut microbiota and intestinal pathogenic bacteria configuration in wild L. ridibundus
column41: even though the public are in close contact with this bird. In this study
column42: 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing methods were used to describe the microbial community structure and intestinal pathogenic bacteria were isolated to identify their characteristics. The taxonomic results revealed that Firmicutes (86%)
column44: and Tenericutes (3%) were the three most abundant phyla in the gut of L. ridibundus. Enterococcaceae
column46: and Mycoplasmataceae were the most predominant families
column47: respectively. The number of operational taxonomic units (OTUs)
column48: the richness estimates and diversity indices of microbiota
column50: beta diversity showed that no statistical significance (p > 0.05) between all the fecal samples. The most frequently isolated intestinal pathogenic bacteria from L. ridibundus were enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (32%) and Salmonella (21%). Pulsedfield gel electrophoresis (PFGE) results of Salmonella species revealed a high degree of similarity between isolates
column51: which was not observed for other species. None of the potentially pathogenic isolates were identical to humanisolated counterparts suggesting that there was little crossinfection between humans and gulls

column100: microbial communities of recently migrated L. ridibundus were analyzed by 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing investigation
column101: and intestinal pathogenic bacteria were isolated to identify their characteristics. 2  | MATERIAL S AND METHODS 2.1 | Sample collection of and DNA extraction Five hundred fecal samples from L. ridibundus were collected in Kunming (103°40′ E
column103: southwest China. The collection was divided into two periods
column104: November and December 2017. The samples were collected around 5–10 m far from each other along the Daguan River in the center of Kunming city. Each sample was handled in two ways; one was by isolation using methods for common intestinal pathogenic bacteria; the other was randomly selecting 86 samples to extract total DNA for 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing analysis. The whole genomic DNA was extracted by using the fecal samples’ DNA extraction kit (Tiangen
column105: Beijing) following the manufacturer’s instructions. In this kit
column106: the genomic DNA of fecal samples was extracted by centrifugal adsorption column with specific binding to total DNA. A unique inhibitor adsorption tablet (InhibitEX)
column107: combined with a specially developed buffer system was also used for extraction. The entire microorganism’s DNA could be extracted efficiently from fecal samples by using this kit. All extracted DNA samples were stored at −20°C for microbial community analysis. 2.2 | PCR
column110: and sequencing The variable region V3–V4 of the 16S rRNA gene was used for the library construction of the bacterial community by Illumina Miseq sequencing. Standard amplicon primers were used (Klindworth et al.
column112: and Illumina adapter overhang nucleotide sequences were added to the genespecific sequences according to the protocol of library preparation guideline. PCR amplifications were performed using KAPA HotStart PCR kits (Kapa
column113: Biosystems). Each PCR reaction included 0.2 M Trehalose
column119: and PCR water totally added up to 25 μl. The amplification conditions were as follows: 95°C for 3 min
column120: followed by 25 cycles of 95°C for 30 s
column123: and final extension at 72°C for 5 min (Bobrova
column127: 2016). The PCR products were purified with AMPure XP magnetic beads (Beckman
column128: Coulter) and quantified using the Qubit fluorometer (Invitrogen
column129: Life Technologies). A secondary amplifications to attach the Illumina Nextera barcodes were then performed
column130: using the i5 forward primer and i7 reverse primer following the manufacturer’s instructions (Kim

column155: the reads were retained and analyzed
column159: 2016) of Genomics Workbench. CLC Microbial Genomics Module and CLC Genomics Workbench performed operational taxonomic units (OTU) clustering and estimated alpha and beta diversities in microbial samples. All the sequences were clustered into OTUs
column160: based on 97% sequence similarity against the Greengenes reference sequence collection (version 13.5) (CornejoGranados et al.
column161: 2017). Taxonomy summaries with relative abundance data were generated. The representative sequences were aligned to the Greengenes reference alignment
column163: then a phylogenic tree was constructed with the UPGMA for tree building. Prior to statistical analysis
column164: the sequencing depths between samples were normalized. Alpha and beta diversity metrics from the final OTUs table were obtained. The alpha diversity analysis
column165: including rarefaction curve and diversity indices
column166: was carried out. The beta diversity was analyzed based on Fast UniFrac (Hamady
column169: 2010). Differences in the alpha and beta diversity were investigated
column173: differences in taxonomic composition were analyzed from the phylum to the family level. Statistical analysis was performed using a Kruskal–Wallis H test in SPSS statistics package
column178: and PERMANOVA analyzed two groups of sampling time (November and December) for multiple testing correction by CLC Microbial Genomics Module (version 1.6.1). p value of <0.05 was recognized as statistical significance. Sequence data were deposited on the NCBI database by the SRA accession: SRP131711. 2.4 | Isolations of the intestinal pathogenic bacteria The intestinal pathogenic bacterial spectrum included diarrheagenic E. coli

column188: and incubated at 37°C for 24 hr. Enrichment was performed using phosphatebuffered saline with sorbitol and bile salts (PSB) incubating at 4°C for 21 days

column193: Salmonella and Yersinia enterocolitica) from L. ridibundus. The procedures were performed according to the protocols of each bacteria published by PulseNet (Curran et al.
column198: 2014). The plugs digested with different enzymes

The diarrhea patients’ PFGE patterns for different surveillance pathogenic bacteria from our previous database were used for comparison purpose. 3  | RESULTS 3.1 | Taxonomic results of the L. ridibundus gut microbiota In total

column299: and Larus ridibundus. Most of the species lived around seashores or rivers
column300: and therefore their feces could be considered as the major source of contamination in coastal and lake waters. Since their migratory character and feeding behavior (Berg & Anderson
column302: public maybe concerned on the possibility of waterfowl fecal contamination in environmental waters for the potential spread of microbial pathogens to humans
column303: domesticated animals and human food sources. However
column304: our actual data in this study did not strongly support this hypothesis. Previous study (Lu et al.
column305: 2011) showed that gull fecal pollution was widespread in urban coastal and riverine areas in North America and that it significantly contributed to fecal indicator bacterial loads. However
column306: the risks associated with exposure to recreational waters impacted by fresh gull
column308: or pig faeces appear substantially lower than waters impacted by human sources (Soller
column313: 2010). As one of species of gulls
column315: thousands of L. ridibundus flied to warm Kunming from remote Siberia for overwintering where the primary habitats were the lakes or rivers in the city. These areas were centralized areas for tourists and citizens where people could contact L. ridibundus. In our study
column316: none of the potentially pathogenic isolates were identical to human isolates counterparts suggested that there was little cross infection between human and gulls regardless of the potential close encounters. It was further suggested that the public health risks of gull fecal pollution (at least this species) were less than human and other animal sources. Several studies showed the gut microbiota of waterfowl
column317: using culturebased methods and mainly concerned on some pathogens (Craven et al.
column319: 2009). Because culturebased studies only provide a limited finding of natural microbial communities
column320: cultureindependent molecular methods can be used to describe the composition of waterfowl gut microbiome. A study referred to 60 mammalian species showed that microbial communities at higher taxonomic levels were very similar between birds and mammals; and most researches showed two phyla
column322: as dominant out of 75 known microbial phyla (Ley
column327: 2008). This analysis result was very interesting
column328: since it was believed that the common ancestor of amniotes (reptiles
column330: and mammals) possessed a microbial community mostly comprising Firmicutes and Bacteroidetes (Costello
column339: 2008) demonstrated that the gull–gut bacterial community was mostly composed of populations closely related to Bacilli (37%)
column342: and Bacteriodetes (1%) in North America. Their study contained seven species of gulls
column343: but did not involve the L. ridibundus. Similar results could be found in our study
column344: the most comprised microbial community was Firmicutes for migrated L. ridibundus; however
column345: Bacteroidetes was not the major composition. Actually
column347: Firmicutes accounted for 54.6% of the microbial community
column349: and Tenericutes was 8.9%. The composition of Firmicutes phyla was lower than ours
column350: and only 85 OTUs were obtained from 282 gull fecal samples. These differences might be due to gull species
column353: while the most important one was different methods to generate the 16S libraries. A clone library method was used in Lu et al. study
column354: and they used different primer compared with ours. In our study
column355: Proteobacteria and Tenericutes phylum were the important communities for this wild bird. A metaanalysis (Waite & Taylor
column356: 2014) of the avian gut metagenome indicated that consistent with the microbiota of vertebrates in general
column357: the avian gut microbiota was found to harbor mostly OTUs belonging to Bacteroidetes
column359: and Proteobacteria. The phylum Firmicutes were present in all samples analyzed
column360: while Proteobacteria and Bacteroidetes were widely distributed as well. Actinobacteria and Tenericutes were also commonly found throughout the data
column361: but the number was relatively small. All these studies involved in the Metaanalysis were using clone library and amplicon pyrosequencing methods. The amplification regions of 16S rRNA gene were also different. Therefore
column362: we considered that the microbiota of L. ridibundus showing some similar characteristics with other avian; meanwhile
column363: some specific features could be found for this species of avian
column364: such as the composition of Tenericutes. Indeed
column365: previous studies have shown that waterfowl feces may carry human pathogens such as Campylobacter spp. (Broman et al.
column385: 2004). The role of wild birds in transmitting pathogens indicated the importance of avian pollution in zoonosis. From our previous studies (Zhang
column392: the most 8 of 9  |     LIAO et AL. predominant bacterial pathogen in diarrhea cases in southwest China was diarrheagenic E. coli
column393: followed by nontyphoidal Salmonella. In this study
column394: the most frequently isolated bacteria from L. ridibundus were EPEC
column396: showing an interesting result. All the EPEC were atypical strains
column398: and the PFGE patterns showed highly heterogeneity for all the strains. However
column399: S. typhimurium accounted for most of isolated Salmonella
column400: and indicated highly similarly among the isolates. Makino et al. (Makino et al.
column401: 2000) found Shiga toxin (Stx)producing E. coli (STEC) strains isolated from a seagull in Japan. Kullas et al. (2002) demonstrated that Canada geese had a high prevalence of diarrheagenic E. coli. In the study of Palmgren et al. (2006)
column402: 83% of isolated Salmonella was S. Typhimurium from L. ridibundus
column403: and indicated this wild bird might play a role in the spread of S. Typhimurium in Sweden. These data have paid useful attention on the risks for wild birds to public health. Although no homology of pathogenic bacteria was found between diarrhea patients and L. ridibundus in our study
column404: this information was critical in order to recognize potential hazards associated with waterfowl fecal pollution. In general
column405: this was the first study to demonstrate the microbial community structure and intestinal pathogenic bacteria from migrated L. ridibundus in southwest China. Firmicutes
column407: and Tenericutes were the three most abundant phyla in the gut of L. ridibundus. The most isolated intestinal pathogenic bacteria from L. ridibundus were enteropathogenic E. coli and Salmonella. Although no homology of pathogenic bacteria was found between diarrhea patients and L. ridibundus
column408: these results provided a baseline for future L. ridibundus microbiology study
column409: and make an understanding of the intestinal bacterial community
